text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

At BiGS leadership roundtable
in Sao Paulo recently,

we heard from CEOs and nonprofit
leaders across Latin America.

Join us as we explore how
businesses are not only

reshaping economies and
communities but also reshaping
lives one investment at a time.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

Thank you so much
for joining us.
It's a pleasure.

We wanted to understand a
little bit about your company.

You are helping improve the
lives of low income Brazilians
with upgrading their housing.

Can you please tell
us about your company?

It's interesting, but in
Brazil and all Latin American

countries, when we
think about housing,

we think that the solution
is to build new units.

But it's an IDB data is
that since the 2000s,

all the countries of
Latin America invested--

90% of the money that
they invested in housing
was to build new units.

Although if we look to
the housing deficit,

it's 94% qualitative
deficit, which

means that we don't need
to build new houses mainly.

We need to adequate-- we need
to renovate those houses.

So what we do at Vivenda is to
offer a solution to low income

families to access solutions
to renovate their houses
and live better.

For people who
don't know Brazil,

can you set this
up a little bit?
How big of a need is this?

If we're thinking
about official data,

we need to work with
25 million houses
to adequate here in Brazil.

This is not half of all
the houses that we have.

But if we consider a more broad,
comprehensive approach, it's--

in Brazil today,
almost half of all the

houses we need to renovate
and they are mainly
low income families' houses.

And what do these
houses look like?
Are they favelas?
Are they standalone houses?
What does it look like?

When we talk about
inadequacy or--

we are talking about
houses that don't

have a window, a
good roof, maybe

they lack of a bathroom,
sanitation, and-- et cetera.

So we have different approaches,
but it's those kind of houses

that you don't feel
100% good inside.

And it seems that
it's taking off

because I understand
you went from one city--

Sao Paulo, which is a
very big city-- and I

think you might be
in 25 right now.
Yeah, we expanded a lot.

Now we are working as-- we are
not more a B2C company anymore,

we are a B2B2C company or
working with governments.

So we offer our solution
to these players

and that's why we
change a little bit
the number of the cities.

So how many cities are you
operating in right now?

Today we are operating
in 14 cities in Brazil.

Can you give us an idea
of which ones they are?
Yeah.

We have big cities like
Sao Paulo, for example,

and we have very small cities,
like Ouro Preto in Minas Gerais
in different contexts.

But the thing is, when we
look to housing deficit

in Brazil, we-- it's
in all the cities.
OK, a lot of demand.

So this sounds like
a really good cause.
Is it a good business?

We at Vivenda, when we began, we
decided to qualify this market
because this is a huge problem.

We need to renovate
25 million houses.

But it's also, in
my point of view,

the biggest civil
construction market in Brazil.

But it's informal, it's
inefficient, and-- et cetera.

So at Vivenda we aim to
develop this market in order

to make it more accessible
for low income families.

And today, after a couple of
years working with this, we

can say that business--
in terms of business,

our operation is way
more financial stable.

And so where do you hope to be
with the company in five years?

Now we are opening negotiation
with the public sector

because, as I am learning--
not only in Brazil

but in other countries of
Latin America-- the solution

that we provide to manage
those programs in housing

and renovations-- it's a
need of not only companies
but also public institutions.

And I think in
five years we will

be spreading this programs
of housing renovations
to more cities in Brazil.

I understand that these could
be homes without basic things.

So what does a typical
renovation look like?
Is it to add a bathroom?
Is it to install windows?

I'm sure it varies greatly, but
please paint a picture for us.
Yeah.

Traditionally, the
houses that we operate we

operate with donation when
public institution or private

decide to donate the
most vulnerable families

and we work with credit for
those families that can afford.

But mainly the
renovation itself is

to open window, waterproofing
the walls, tiling, and painting.
We need to match static--
statics with health.
This is our challenge.

At the end of the day,
the bathroom or the room,

it's a beautiful place to
be and this is what we do.

It doesn't sound easy,
though, because you
may have coding issues.
These buildings may have been--

I don't know, people
may or may not

have been doing
things themselves.

It sounds like it's not
very easy all the time.
It may be difficult.

No, each renovation is a
renovation in all the world.

If you consider favelas, that
is people producing their houses

without a pattern, et cetera,
it's even more difficult,
but this is our work.
OK, great.

Can you walk us through
a recent example

when you've attended-- maybe
you've attended a big reveal,

maybe you've visited a family
in their renovated home?
What is the feeling like?
How happy are they?

It's interesting because when
we think about renovation,

civil construction
in this case of home

renovations for low
income families,

the impact is not related
to the renovation itself.

Every time I ask to a client,
So what's your life now?

What was the impact
of your new bathroom?

they always say, I stopped
fighting with my husband,

my kid is studying more,
and-- et cetera, et cetera--

nothing related to
the renovation itself.

The point is when we
renovate an inadequate house,

it's a spark of development
for all other dimensions

of their lives because
the house is the place--
is the basis of development.

So this is the
beauty of this work.

You're not only
improving the space,

but you're improving the
whole dynamic of life inside.

Can you tell us a
little bit about them?

Are they-- is the
average client or--
a double working family?
Do they have two kids?

I'm sure it varies, but
give us an average client.
Yeah.

Almost 90% of our clients
are women and most of them
are chief of the family.

They work, they take care of the
kids, and they do everything.

So that's why our
turnkey solution

is a good option
because they don't
need to manage the bricklayer.

They don't need
to buy materials.

They need the solution
done and that's what we do.
Great.
And is there an average cost?
Is there-- is it a--

what's the average
dollar amount?

The average cost is
about $1,200, yeah,

and today they pay up
to 30 installments.
Wow.
Thank you so much.

Anything else you'd like
to share about Vivenda?

Yeah, we spent about eight years
understanding and developing

this market and we
deliver about 500--
5,000 renovation, I'm sorry.

And now we became a
technology company.

We are not executing renovations
anymore because we understand

that using technology
is the way that we
scale even more our operation.

For example, only in 2024, with
one contract with the city hall,

we will deliver
5,000 renovation.

So we are really
scaling what we did.

And it's only possible because
we are not the executors

anymore, but we are enabling
all the actors of the markets

to work in a safety way
with us, with our platform.
